item.title: The Inconvenient Convenience of Dynamic Languages
item.description: Truthiness is the behavior of interpreting non-boolean values as true or false in a conditional context. E.g. in this loop: while 1 { ... }, the 1 is interpreted as true. Dynamic programming languages provide this behavior as a convenience to save the programmer from typing more than they need to.
